{{Infobox UNESCO World Heritage Site | WHS = Rock Shelters of Bhimbetka | image = Rock Shelter 8, Bhimbetka 02.jpg | image_upright = 1.2 | caption = Bhimbetka rock painting | location = [[Raisen District]], [[Madhya Pradesh]], [[India]] | Type = Cultural | criteria = (iii), (v) | ID = 925 | coordinates = {{coord|22.938415|N|77.613085|E|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | year = 2003 | area = {{convert|1,893|ha|sqmi|abbr=on}} | buffer_zone = {{convert|10,280|ha|sqmi|abbr=on}} | locmapin = India#India Madhya Pradesh | map_caption = Bhimbetka rock shelters, Madhya Pradesh, India }} The '''Bhimbetka rock shelters''' are an archaeological site in central [[India]] that spans the prehistoric [[paleolithic]] and [[mesolithic]] periods, as well as the historic period.<ref name="PeregrineEmber2003p315">{{cite book|author1=Peter N. Peregrine|author2=Melvin Ember|title=Encyclopedia of Prehistory: Volume 8: South and Southwest Asia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C-TQpUtI-dgC&pg=PA315 |year=2003|publisher=Springer Science |isbn=978-0-306-46262-7|pages=315–317}}</ref><ref name=alip15/> It exhibits the earliest traces of human life on the [[Indian subcontinent]] and evidence of [[Stone Age]] starting at the site in [[Acheulian]] times.<ref>{{cite web |title= Chronology of Indian prehistory from the Mesolithic period to the Iron Age|url= https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0047248478800347 |quote=The microlithic occupation there is the last one, as the Stone Age started there with Acheulian times. These rock shelters have been used to light fires even up to recent times by the tribals. This is re-fleeted in the scatter of 14C dates from Bhimbetka}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=07HGDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT7|title=A Short History of India: From the Earliest Civilisations to Today's Economic Powerhouse|page=17|publisher=Oldcastle Books Ltd|first=Gordon|last=Kerr|isbn=9781843449232|date=2017-05-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author1=Neda Hosse in Tehrani|author2= Shahida Ansari| author3= Kamyar Abdi| title=ANTHROPOGENIC PROCESSES IN CAVES/ROCK SHELTERS IN IZEH PLAIN (IRAN) AND BHIMBETKA REGION (INDIA): AN ETHNO-ARCHAEOLOGICAL PERSPECTIVE|journal=Bulletin of the Deccan College Research Institute| volume=76| year=2016|quote=the rock shelter site of Bhimbetka in Madhya Pradesh exhibits the earliest traces of human life|jstor= 26264790}}</ref> It is located in the [[Raisen District]] in the [[India]]n state of [[Madhya Pradesh]] about {{convert|45|km}} southeast of [[Bhopal]]. It is a UNESCO world heritage site that consists of seven hills and over 750 rock shelters distributed over {{convert|10|km}}.<ref name=alip15>Javid, Ali and Javeed, Tabassum (2008), ''World Heritage Monuments and Related Edifices in India'', Algora Publishing, 2008, pages 15–19</ref><ref>[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/925/documents/ Rock Shelters of Bhimbetka: Advisory Body Evaluation], UNESCO, pages 43–44</ref> At least some of the shelters were inhabited more than 100,000 years ago.<ref name="alip15"/><ref>[http://whc.unesco.org/uploads/nominations/925.pdf Rock Shelters of Bhimbetka: Advisory Body Evaluation], UNESCO, pages 14–15</ref> The rock shelters and caves provide evidence of, according to Encyclopædia Britannica, and a "rare glimpse" into human settlement and cultural evolution from hunter-gatherers, to agriculture, and expressions of spirituality.<ref name=britannicabhimbetka/>
Some of the Bhimbetka rock shelters feature prehistoric [[cave painting]]s and the earliest are about 30,000 years old.<ref name="klostermaier1989">{{Citation | title=A survey of Hinduism | author=Klaus K. Klostermaier | authorlink = Klaus Klostermaier | year=1989 | isbn=0-88706-807-3 | publisher=SUNY Press | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ltn3OuF_i4sC | quote=''... prehistoric cave paintings at Bhimbetka (ca. 30000 BCE) ...''}}</ref> These cave paintings show themes such as animals, early evidence of dance and hunting.<ref name=bhim3/><ref name=bhim1/> The Bhimbetka site has the oldest known rock art in the Indian subcontinent,<ref name="Pearsall2008p1951">{{cite book|author=Deborah M. Pearsall|title= Encyclopedia of archaeology|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=RnoUAQAAIAAJ|year =2008|publisher =Elsevier Academic Press|isbn=978-0-12-373643-7|pages=1949–1951}}</ref> as well as is one of the largest prehistoric complexes.<ref name=britannicabhimbetka/><ref>{{cite book|author1=Jo McDonald|author2=Peter Veth|title=A Companion to Rock Art|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=excwzC1zhY0C&pg=PT291|year=2012|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-118-25392-2|pages=291–293}}</ref>
== Etymology == The name ''Bhimbetka'' (भीमबेटका) is associated with [[Bhima]], a hero-deity of the epic ''[[Mahabharata]]''.<ref name=mathpal>[[Yashodhar Mathpal|Mathpal, Yashodhar]]. ''Prehistoric Painting Of Bhimbetka''. 1984, page 25</ref> The word ''Bhimbetka'' is said to derive from ''Bhimbaithka'' (भीमबैठका), meaning "sitting place of Bhima".<ref name=mathpal />
== Location == {{double image|right|Path way Bhembetika (2).jpg|160|Information Palette Bhimbetka (3).jpg|160|Bhimbetka location}} The Rock Shelters of Bhimbetaka (or Bhim Baithaka) is 45 kilometers southeast of [[Bhopal]] and 9 km from [[Obedullaganj]] city in the [[Raisen District]] of [[Madhya Pradesh]] at the southern edge of the [[Vindhya Range|Vindhya]] hills. South of these rock shelters are successive ranges of the [[Satpura]] hills. It is inside the ''[[Ratapani Wildlife Sanctuary]]'', embedded in sandstone rocks, in the foothills of the Vindhya Range.<ref name=britannicabhimbetka>[https://www.britannica.com/place/Bhimbetka-rock-shelters Bhimbetka rock shelters], Encyclopaedia Britannica</ref><ref>[http://whc.unesco.org/uploads/nominations/925.pdf Rock Shelters of Bhimbetka: Continuity through Antiquity, Art & Environment], Archaeological Survey of India, UNESCO, pages 14–18, 22–23, 30–33</ref> The site consists of seven hills: Vinayaka, Bhonrawali, Bhimbetka, Lakha Juar (east and west), Jhondra and Muni Babaki Pahari.<ref name="PeregrineEmber2003p315"/>
== History == [[File:1 of the rock shelter caves at Bhimbetka, Madhya Pradesh.jpg|thumb|One of about 750 rock shelter caves at Bhimbetka.]]
W. Kincaid, a British India era official, first mentioned Bhimbetka in a scholarly paper in 1888. He relied on the information he gathered from local [[adivasi]]s (tribals) about Bhojpur lake in the area and referred to Bhimbetka as a [[Buddhist]] site.<ref name=asiunesco54>[http://whc.unesco.org/uploads/nominations/925.pdf Rock Shelters of Bhimbetka: Continuity through Antiquity, Art & Environment], Archaeological Survey of India, UNESCO, page 54</ref> The first archaeologist to visit a few caves at the site and discover its prehistoric significance was [[V. S. Wakankar]], who saw these rock formations and thought these were similar to those he had seen in Spain and France. He visited the area with a team of archaeologists and reported several prehistoric rock shelters in 1957.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/pg.cfm?cid=31&id_site=925|title=Rock Shelters of Bhimbetka|publisher=World Heritage Site|accessdate=2007-02-15| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070308082739/http://whc.unesco.org/pg.cfm?cid=31&id_site=925| archivedate= 8 March 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
It was only in the 1970s that the scale and true significance of the Bhimbetka rock shelters was discovered and reported.<ref name=asiunesco54/> Since then, more than 750 rock shelters have been identified. The Bhimbetka group contains 243 of these, while the Lakha Juar group nearby has 178 shelters. According to Archaeological Survey of India, the evidence suggests that there has been a continuous human settlement here from the [[Stone Age]] through the late [[Acheulian]] to the late [[Mesolithic]] until the 2nd-century BCE in these hills. This is based on excavations at the site, the discovered artifacts and wares, pigments in deposits, as well as the rock paintings.<ref name=bhimbetka15>[http://whc.unesco.org/uploads/nominations/925.pdf Rock Shelters of Bhimbetka: Continuity through Antiquity, Art & Environment], Archaeological Survey of India, UNESCO, pages 15–16, 22–23, 45, 54–60</ref>
The site contains the world’s oldest stone walls and floors.<ref>{{cite book|title=Indian Rock Art and Its Global Context|author1=Kalyan Kumar Chakravarty|author2=Robert G. Bednarik|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass|page=29}}</ref>
[[Barkheda, Raisen|Barkheda]] has been identified as the source of the raw materials used in some of the monoliths discovered at Bhimbetka.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://whc.unesco.org/archive/advisory_body_evaluation/925.pdf | title = Bhimbetka (India) No. 925 | publisher = UNESCO World Heritage Centre | accessdate = 2012-04-28 }}</ref>
The site consisting of 1,892 hectares was declared as protected under Indian laws and came under the management of the Archaeological Survey of India in 1990.<ref>[http://whc.unesco.org/uploads/nominations/925.pdf Rock Shelters of Bhimbetka: Continuity through Antiquity, Art & Environment], Archaeological Survey of India, UNESCO, pages 10, 53</ref> It was declared as a world heritage site by UNESCO in 2003.<ref name=britannicabhimbetka/><ref>[http://asi.nic.in/asi_monu_whs_rockart_bhimbetka.asp World Heritage Sites – Rock Shelters of Bhimbetka], Archaeological Survey of India</ref>
== Auditorium cave == {{double image|right|Entrance of bhimbetka.jpg|160|Entry to "Auditorium Cave".jpg|160|Bhimbetka quartzite towers.|Auditorium cave.}} Of the numerous shelters, the Auditorium cave is one of the significant features of the site. Surrounded by quartzite towers which are visible from several kilometers distance, the Auditorium rock is the largest shelter at Bhimbetka. Robert Bednarik describes the prehistoric Auditorium cave as one with a "cathedral-like" atmosphere, with "its Gothic arches and soaring spaces".<ref name=bednarik63/> Its plan resembles a "right-angled cross" with four of its branches aligned to the four cardinal directions. The main entrance points to the east. At the end of this eastern passage, at the cave's entrance, is a boulder with a near-vertical panel that is distinctive, one visible from distance and all directions. In archaeology literature, this boulder has been dubbed as "Chief's Rock" or "King's Rock", though there is no evidence of any rituals or its role as such.<ref name=bednarik63/><ref>Robert Bednarik (1993), Palaeolithic Art in India, ''Man and Environment'', Volume 18, Number 2, pages 33–40</ref><ref>{{cite book | last=Singh | first=Manoj Kumar | title=Encyclopedia of Global Archaeology | chapter=Bhimbetka Rockshelters | publisher=Springer New York | year=2014 | isbn=978-1-4419-0426-3 | doi=10.1007/978-1-4419-0465-2_2286 | pages=867–870}}</ref> The boulder with the Auditorium Cave is the central feature of the Bhimbetka, midst its 754 numbered shelters spread over few kilometers on either side, and nearly 500 locations where rock paintings can be found, states Bednarik.<ref name=bednarik63>Robert G Bednarik (1996), The cupules on Chief's Rock, Auditorium Cave, Bhimbetka, The Artifact: Journal of the Archaeological and Anthropological Society of Victoria, Volume 19, pages 63–71</ref>
== Rock art and paintings == [[File:Rock Shelter 15, Bhimbetka 02.jpg|thumb|250px|The only painting in the caves showing, "a man" being hunted by a beast, a horned boar.]] [[File:Bhimbetka_Natraj_painting.jpg|thumb|upright|An eroded painting in the Bhimbetka caves shows "Nataraj" dancing and holding a ''trishula'' or trident.]]
The rock shelters and caves of Bhimbetka have a large number of paintings. The oldest paintings are found to be 30,000 years old, but some of the geometric figures date to as recently as the [[Middle Ages|medieval period]]. The colors used are vegetable colors which have endured through time because the drawings were generally made deep inside a niche or on inner walls. The drawings and paintings can be classified under seven different periods.
'''Period I''' – ([[Upper Paleolithic]]): These are linear representations, in green and dark red, of huge figures of animals such as [[bison]], [[tiger]]s and [[rhinoceros]]es.
'''Period II''' – ([[Mesolithic]]): Comparatively small in size the stylised figures in this group show linear decorations on the body. In addition to animals there are human figures and hunting scenes, giving a clear picture of the weapons they used: barbed [[spear]]s, pointed sticks, [[bow and arrow|bows and arrows]].<ref name=bhim3/><ref name=bhim1/><ref name=bhim2/> Some scenes are interpreted as depicting tribal war between three tribes symbolised by their animal totems.<ref name="PeregrineEmber2003p315"/><ref>{{cite book|title=South Asian Prehistory: A Multidisciplinary study|author=D. P. Agrawal, J. S. Kharakwal |page=149 |publisher =Aryan Books International}}</ref> The depiction of communal dances, birds, musical instruments, mothers and children, pregnant women, men carrying dead animals, drinking and burials appear in rhythmic movement.<ref name=bhim3>Yashodhar Mathpal, 1984, [https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=GG7-CpvlU30C&pg=PA214 Prehistoric Painting Of Bhimbetka], Page 214.</ref><ref name=bhim1>M. L. Varad Pande, Manohar Laxman Varadpande, 1987, [https://books.google.com.sg/books?isbn=8170172217 History of Indian Theatre], Volume 1, Page 57.</ref><ref name=bhim2>[https://books.google.com.sg/books?isbn=8170171539 Dance In Indian Painting], Page xv.</ref>
'''Period III''' – ([[Chalcolithic]]) Similar to the paintings of the Mesolithic, these drawings reveal that during this period the cave dwellers of this area were in contact with the agricultural communities of the [[Malwa]] plains, exchanging goods with them.
'''Period IV & V''' – (Early historic): The figures of this group have a schematic and decorative style and are painted mainly in red, white and yellow. The association is of riders, depiction of religious symbols, tunic-like dresses and the existence of scripts of different periods. The religious beliefs are represented by figures of [[yaksha]]s, tree gods and magical sky chariots.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
'''Period VI & VII''' – (Medieval) : These paintings are geometric linear and more schematic, but they show degeneration and crudeness in their artistic style. The colors used by the cave dwellers were prepared by combining black [[manganese oxide]]s, red [[hematite]] and [[charcoal]].
One rock, popularly referred to as “Zoo Rock”, depicts [[elephant]]s, [[barasingha]] (swamp deer), [[bison]] and [[deer]]. Paintings on another rock show a [[peacock]], a [[snake]], a deer and the sun. On another rock, two elephants with tusks are painted. Hunting scenes with hunters carrying bows, arrows, swords and shields also find their place in the community of these pre-historic paintings. In one of the caves, a bison is shown in pursuit of a hunter while his two companions appear to stand helplessly nearby; in another, some horsemen are seen, along with archers. In one painting, a large wild boar is seen.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}<!-- Which period?!? -->
The paintings are classified largely in two groups, one as depiction of hunters and food gatherers, while other one as fighters, riding on horses and elephant carrying metal weapons. the first group of paintings dates to prehistoric times while second one dates to historic times.<ref>{{cite book|title=Prehistoric Painting Of Bhimbetka|page=225|publisher=Abhinav Publications|year=1984|first=Yashodhar|last=Mathpal}}</ref><ref name=Javidp20>{{cite book| author =Javid, Ali and Javeed, Tabassum |title=World Heritage Monuments and Related Edifices in India|publisher=Algora Publishing|year= 2008|page=20}}</ref> Most of the paintings from historic period depicts battles between the rulers carrying swords, spears, bows and arrows.<ref name=Javidp20/>
In one of the desolate rock shelters, the painting of a man holding a trident-like staff and dancing has been named "[[Nataraj]]" by archaeologist [[V. S. Wakankar]].<ref>{{cite book|title= Rock-art of India: Paintings and Engravings|page=123|publisher=Arnold-Heinemann|first=Kalyan Kumar|last=Chakravarty|quote=Nataraj figures from BHIM III E-19 and one from III F −16 are well decorated in fierce mood. Probably they represent conception of a fierce deity like Vedic Rudra.(Wa.kankar, op. cit)'.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Riddles of Indian Rockshelter Paintings|author=Shiv Kumar Tiwari|page=245|publisher=Sarup & Sons}}</ref> It is estimated that paintings in at least 100 rockshelters might have been eroded away.<ref>{{cite book|title=After the Ice: A Global Human History, 20,000–5000 BC|page=401|first=Steven|last=Mithen|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=2006|isbn=9780674019997}}</ref>

page.title: Cerro de la Estrella National Park

revision.comment: /* Natural history */
revision.text:
[[File:Cerro de la Estrella.jpg|thumb|Walking path in Cerro de la Estrella National Park.]] '''Cerro de la Estrella National Park''' is centered on the Cerro de la Estrella mountain which is located entirely within eastern Mexico City, in the borough of [[Iztapalapa]].
The park was originally designated in 1938 with 1,100 hectares, but the growth of the city has encroached on it and left it with less than 200 hectares. The park is meant to provide cultural and recreational opportunity as well as to protect the mountain, which is important archaeologically and culturally as the site of the pre Hispanic [[New Fire ceremony]] and the modern-day [[Passion Play of Iztapalapa|Passion Play]]. Archaeological remains include temples related to the ceremony and older structures such as housing units, [[petroglyph]]s, and a major temple related to the [[Teotihuacan]] culture. The park and the archaeological sites remain in danger of destruction by encroachment, use of land for agriculture, graffiti and the dumping of garbage.
==Description== The park was originally declared in 1938 with about 1,100 hectares but today it is considered to have somewhere between 143 and 192.<ref name="itzagob">{{cite web |url=http://www.iztapalapa.gob.mx/htm/0505010000_2005.html |title=Parque Cerro de la Estrella |publisher=Borough of Iztapalapa |location=Mexico City |language=Spanish |trans-title=Cerro de la Estrella Park |accessdate=June 12, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name="invasion">{{cite news |title= Invasión de paracaidistas pone en riesgo valiosos bienes culturales, denuncian |author= Carlos Paul |url= http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2011/08/03/cultura/a07n1cul |newspaper=La Jornada |location=Mexico City |date=August 3, 2011 |page=7 |accessdate=June 12, 2012 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Denounce invasion of illegal settlers putting valuable cultural riches at risk }}</ref> The park is completely within [[Mexico City]],<ref name="archeologia">{{cite web |url= http://www.mexicocity.gob.mx/contenido.php?cat=30300&sub=0 |title= Arqueología |publisher= Government of Mexico City |location=Mexico City |language=Spanish |trans-title=Archeology |accessdate=June 12, 2012 }}</ref> located in the borough of [[Iztapalapa]] bordering the boroughs of [[Tláhuac]] and [[Milpa Alta]], bordered by major thoroughfares such as Calzada Ermita Iztapalapa and Calzada México-Tulyehualca.<ref name="redescolar">{{cite web |url= http://redescolar.ilce.edu.mx/redescolar/publicaciones/publi_prodigios/ce_estrella/estrella.htm |title= Parque Nacional Cerro de la Estrella |publisher= [[Instituto Latinoamericano de la Comunicación Educativa]] |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |trans-title=Cerro de la Estrella National Park |accessdate=June 12, 2012 }}</ref>
Most of the administration of the park falls under the Secretaría de Agricultura y Recursos Hidráulicos, with the objectives being a recreational and cultural zone for the borough to increase tourism.<ref name="redescolar"/> Of all the parks and green spaces in the city, it is the most abused with seasonal farming, illegal human settlements, areas used for grazing, the extraction of minerals, the dumping of garbage and even a cemetery.<ref name="archeologia"/> A wall has been constructed around parts of the park to protect it, especially the archeological site, from further encroachments by surrounding neighborhoods.<ref name="itzagob"/><ref name="archeologia"/>
==Natural history== The park is centered on the Cerro de la Estrella, a small mountain {{convert|2450|m|ft}} above sea level and {{convert|224|m|ft}} about the city.<ref name="itzagob"/> It is the highest point in the borough of [[Iztapalapa]].<ref name="fuegoitza">{{cite web |url=http://www.iztapalapa.gob.mx/museo_fuegonuevo/fires/mus0.htm |title=Ubicación del Museo del Fuego Nuevo |publisher=Borough of Iztapalapa |location=Mexico City |language=Spanish |trans-title=Location of the New Fire Museum |accessdate=June 12, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070722180631/http://www.iztapalapa.gob.mx/museo_fuegonuevo/fires/mus0.htm |archivedate=July 22, 2007 |df= }}</ref> The hill is also called Huizachtepetl which means “mountain of thorns.” It was made by volcanic processes, as part of the small mountain chain in the [[Valley of Mexico]] called the Sierra de Santa Catarina. The area serves as a recharge area for aquifers to the east of the city.
The original wildlife of the area is extinct, and most animals here now are rodents, including squirrels. The trees are mostly [[Eucalyptus]], ''[[Pinus patula]]'' pine, and some white cedar, all planted in [[reforestation]] projects.<ref name="itzagob"/><ref name="expertos">{{cite news |title= Se unen expertos a la conservación integral del Cerro de la Estrella |url= http://www.excelsior.com.mx/index.php?m=nota&seccion=especial-comunidad-expresiones&cat=60&id_nota=732816 |newspaper=Excelsior |location=Mexico City |date=April 28, 2007 |accessdate=June 12, 2012 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Gather together experts to conserve the integrity of Cerro de la Estrella }}</ref>
[[File:View from Cerro de la Estrella (Mexico DF) towards the North, with Central de Abastos in the foreground, May 3013.png|thumb|450px|Hilltop view of [[Mexico City]] from the park.]]
==Recreation== Recreational facilities include picnic tables, grills, playgrounds, sports facility and a lookout point.<ref name="itzagob"/><ref name="redescolar"/> Sporting activities practiced in the park include hiking and running.<ref name="redescolar"/> The picnic area is administered by the borough and the Secretariat of Education, which provides activities for schoolchildren. The lookout point at the top of the hill provides one of the best views of the city. It has benches with pre Hispanic motifs and five telescopes for viewing.<ref name="itzagob"/>
The park is filled with small caves, especially on the mountain proper. These caves have been a source of ghost stories and legends in the area, which include stories about the Devil, and youths lost in them. Another states that there is a tunnel under the hill that connects with a cemetery.<ref name="drama">{{cite news |title= Cerro de la Estrella: Drama Ecologico |author= Tatiana Adalid |newspaper=Reforma |location=Mexico City |date=April 18, 1999 |page=1 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Cerro de la Estrella:Ecological Drama }}</ref>
The hill and park are the scene of the annual Passion Play, which ascends the main road of the park to the Museo del Fuego Nuevo .<ref name="fuegoitza"/> The Passion Play attracts thousands of visitors each year with its highlight being the reenactment of the Crucifixion at a place called Calvario but is really the base of a Teotihuacan era pyramid.<ref name="drama"/><ref name="pendiente">{{cite news |title=Pendiente, la declaratoria del Cerro de la Estrella |url=http://www.milenio.com/cdb/doc/impreso/7041650 |newspaper=Milenio |location=Mexico City |date=April 2, 2007 |accessdate=June 12, 2012 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Pending a declaration for the Cerro de la Estrella }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==History== The park was established by President [[Lázaro Cárdenas]] in 1938, with an original area of 1,100 hectares. However, the growth of Mexico City has encroached on the park, despite various attempts to protect it, reducing its size by about ninety percent and stripping away all of its wild vegetation. The trees there now are due to reforestation efforts.<ref name="itzagob"/>
===Mesoamerican=== The area of the park was inhabited from at least the [[Mesoamerican chronology|mid Pre Classic period]], to the [[Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire|Spanish conquest]] and for the most part, the present day. Very early settlements were village and on near the mountain’s slopes. The largest settlement near the mountain was [[Culhuacán (altepetl)|Culhuacan]], founded around 900 CE by the [[Chichimeca]]. By the 15th century, the [[Mexica]]s had control of the area.<ref name=INAH>{{cite web|url=http://www.gobiernodigital.inah.gob.mx/ZonasArqueologicas/todas/htme/za00702.html |title=Méndez Martínez, Enrique Cerro de la Estrella, INAH Official Web Page |date= |publisher=[[INAH]] |location= |language=Spanish |accessdate=September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215060303/http://www.gobiernodigital.inah.gob.mx/ZonasArqueologicas/todas/htme/za00702.html |archivedate=2010-12-15 |df= }}</ref>
During the [[pre-Columbian]] period, the Cerro de la Estrella was called Huizachtecatl, or Sacred Mountain, the site of the [[New Fire ceremony]] performed once every 52 years. The most important archeological remains in the park are related to this. The last New Fire ceremony took place in 1507.<ref name="archeologia"/><ref name=INAH/> Today, the hill remains important culturally, as the scene of Iztapalapa’s annual Passion Play.<ref name="pendiente"/>
====Archeology==== {{main|Cerro de la Estrella (archeological site)}} Archeological finds at the [[Cerro de la Estrella (archeological site)|Cerro de la Estrella archeological site]] relate to the Teotihuacan, [[Toltec]], Chichimeca and Culhua-Mexica cultures and range from 1500 BCE to 1521. Excavations have found the Temple of the New Fire, the Sanctuary, the Villa Estrellas, 144 caves, the remains of walls and evidence of terracing.<ref name="pendiente"/> The most important of these is the former plaza and temple of the New Fire Ceremony, which is on the top of the hill.<ref name="itzagob"/> This archeological site can be visited through a guided tour.<ref name="redescolar"/>
However, early archeological remains can be found in many parts of the park, including those which have since been covered over by urban sprawl.<ref name=INAH/>
Ceramic and stone sculpture materials were discovered in the west side of Huizachtecatl that apparently was made within the 100 to 500 years CE; these resemble other similar pieces found in Zacatenco, north of Mexico City. The constructions here were built between the year 100 and 650 AD and are located in the north side, the remains consist of foundations and walls of palaces that show Teotihuacán influence. Another area was housing zone at the middle of the hill, built during the late Classic period (600 to 900 CE).<ref name="itzagob"/><ref name=INAH /> In 2003, specialists from the Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia (INAH) worked to document petroglyphs found in various areas of the park, registering 210 in eleven groups, but they believe there are still more. Some of the petroglyphs are aligned with certain annual solar events.<ref name="invasion"/>
The most recent find was in 2006, when a pyramid base was discovered in what is called Calvary at the top of the mountain. This base dates to the Teotihuacan period, about 1300 years ago.<ref name="revela">{{cite news |title= Revela Iztapalapa su Templo Mayor. |author=Yanireth Israde |newspaper=Reforma |location=Mexico City |date=August 2, 2007 |page=6 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Iztapalapa reveals its Grand Temple }}</ref> INAH has decided not to excavate the base.<ref name="defienden">{{cite news |title= Defienden Cerro de la Estrella |author= Laura Castellanos |newspaper=Reforma |location=Mexico City |date=May 11, 2006 |page=6 |language=Spanish |trans-title=They defend Cerro de la Estrella }}</ref>
==Threats to park==
===Encroachment + appropriation=== Since its establishment in 1938, the park has shrunk in size from 1,100 hectares to somewhere between 143 and 192 hectares.<ref name="itzagob"/><ref name="invasion"/> This is due to illegal settlements and other encroachment onto the land, which even includes the Panteón Civil San Nicolás Tolentino cemetery in the original designated area.<ref name="defienden"/> The settlements have been made by groups of poor people, unable to purchase or rent living space. Later these groups organize to regularize their possession of the land. Some of this has not be by the poor, but by those able to build houses and buy cars shortly after they have legal possession of the land.<ref name="invasion"/>
To try and stop this process various other laws and declarations have been applied to the areas including declaring et a Zona Ecological y Cultural of Mexico City in 1999 and putting under the Ley Federal sobre Monumentos y Zonas Arqueológicos, Artísticos e Históricos in 2007.<ref name="invasion"/><ref name="drama"/><ref name="pendiente"/> However, these efforts have not been sufficient to guarantee the preservation of the park.<ref name="pendiente"/> As of 2009, there were about 180 families inside the park proper.<ref name="barda">{{cite news |title= Inauguran barda perimetral del Cerro de la Estrella. |newspaper=NOTIMEX |location=Mexico City |date=February 2, 2009 |page=6 |language=Spanish |trans-title=Inaugurate the perimeter wall of the Cerro de la Estrella }}</ref> The 2007 effort made the park and some areas outside an archeological zone under [[INAH]], but the agency has not acted to move those living within the area. Instead it only requires that buildings be no more than two stories tall and to be notified before any major excavation so that salvage operations can be done.<ref name="defienden"/> One last effort to stop encroachment, especially in the major archeological areas as been two stretches of border wall, the last constructed in 2009.<ref name="barda"/>
Another danger to the land is the appropriation of it for use for growing crops and as pasture, with fires lit in the area to clear space.<ref name="redescolar"/>
===Destruction=== Most of the danger archeologically has been to the numerous petroglyphs and caves in the park area. The park contains over 200 petroglyphs at risk of destruction. The Matlolotzin group of petroglyphs are found on the south side of the hill and are the most damaged by graffiti. Some have even been erased by the use to acid to give the impression that there is no heritage here to save.<ref name="invasion"/>
There are also more than 110 small caves which are important geologically and culturally, with evidence of human habitation over various epochs. Some of the more accessible caves have been damaged by people, including Concheros dancers using them for ceremonies.<ref name="invasion"/> The Passion Play attracts thousands of visitors who also damage areas including caves.<ref name="drama"/>
Many of the caves were sealed off by those who took over the land and more have been filed with garbage and graffiti.<ref name="drama"/>

{{About|the church building in present Turkey|the church in the Vatican City|St. Peter's Basilica|other uses|St. Peter's (disambiguation)|and|St. Peter's Church (disambiguation)}} {{ref improve|date=March 2013}} [[Image:Antioch_Saint_Pierre_Church_Front.JPG|300px|thumb|right|Facade of the Church of St Peter, originally built ca. 1100 by Crusaders and rebuilt in the 19th century]] The '''Church of [[Saint Peter]]''' ([[Aramaic]]: ''Knisset Mar Semaan Kefa'', [[Turkish language|Turkish]]: ''Senpiyer Kilisesi'', St. Peter's [[cave-church|Cave Church]], Cave-Church of St. Peter) near [[Antakya]] ([[Antioch]]), [[Turkey]], is composed of a cave carved into the mountainside on Mount Starius with a depth of 13 m (42 ft.), a width of 9.5 m (31 ft.) and a height of 7 m (23 ft). This cave, which some believe was used by the very first [[Early Christians|Christians]], is one of [[Christianity]]'s oldest [[Church (building)|churches]].
==History of congregation and church building== Some people believe that the founding of the [[Early centers of Christianity#Antioch|church in Antioch]] can be traced to the Biblical ''[[Acts of the Apostles]]'' (11:25-27), which relates that [[Barnabas]] travelled to [[Tarsus (city)|Tarsus]] to bring [[Paul the Apostle]] there. They worked for a year with the nascent Christian community, and their adherents to the faith were called "[[Christians]]" for the first time. Christian tradition considers the apostle Peter to be the founder of the church of Antioch and the first priest of the Christian population established there; the Church of St. Peter is traditionally considered to be at the place where he first preached the [[Gospel]] in Antioch.
The oldest surviving parts of the church building date from at least the 4th or 5th century; these include some pieces of floor [[mosaic]]s, and traces of [[fresco]]es on the right side of the [[altar]]. The tunnel inside which opens to the mountainside is thought to have served the Christians for evacuation of the church in case of sudden raids and attacks. Water which seeps from the nearby rocks was gathered inside to drink and to use for [[baptism]]; flow of this water, which visitors drank and collected to give to those who were ill (believing that it was healing and curative), has lessened as a result of recent earthquakes.<ref>Clyde E. Fant, Mitchell Glenn Reddish, [https://books.google.com/books?id=248rXe16v9YC&source=gbs_navlinks_s A guide to biblical sites in Greece and Turkey] (Oxford University Press US, 2003), pg. 149</ref>
Crusaders of the [[First Crusade]] who captured Antakya in 1098 lengthened the church by a few meters and connected it with two arches to the facade, which they constructed. Acting on orders from [[Pope Pius IX]], [[Capuchin Friars]] restored the church and rebuilt the facade in 1863; French Emperor [[Napoleon III]] contributed to the restoration. The remains to the left of the entrance belong to colonnades which formerly stood in front of the present facade.
Atop the stone altar in the middle of the church is a stonework platform placed in memory of [[Saint Peter]]'s Platform Holiday, which was celebrated every 21 February in Antakya. A marble statue of Saint Peter was placed above the altar in 1932.
The garden of the church has been used as a cemetery for hundreds of years. Graves and burials have also been located inside the church, especially around the altar. The church is one of the three final resting places of the remains of the Holy Roman Emperor [[Frederick Barbarossa]], who died in the [[Third Crusade]].
The church is a museum today, but it is possible to perform worship services inside the church under the inspection of the Museum Management by obtaining a permit from the Office of the Provincial Governor.

The '''Cultural Objects Name Authority''' (CONA) is a project by the [[Getty Research Institute]] to create a [[controlled vocabulary]] containing authority records for cultural works, including architecture and movable works such as paintings, sculpture, prints, drawings, manuscripts, photographs, textiles, ceramics, furniture, other visual media such as frescoes and architectural sculpture, performance art, archaeological artifacts, and various functional objects that are from the realm of material culture and of the type collected by museums.<ref name="Discovery and use of art images on the web: an overview">{{cite book|title=Short proceedings of the Third International Euro-Mediterranean Conference EuroMed|year=2010|publisher=Archaeolingua Publ.|isbn=978-963-9911-16-1|pages=205–211 [207]|url=http://hdl.handle.net/1942/11909|author=Krassimira, I.|authorlink=Discovery and use of art images on the web: an overview|editor=Ioannides, M. |editor2=D. Fellner |editor3=A. Georgopoulos |editor4=D. Hadjimitsis |accessdate=2 April 2013|format=Proceedings Paper|display-authors=etal}}</ref> The focus of CONA is works cataloged in scholarly literature, museum collections, visual resources collections, archives, libraries, and indexing projects with a primary emphasis on art, architecture, or archaeology. The target users are the visual resources, academic, and museum communities.<ref name="Introduction to Controlled Vocabularies: Terminology for Art, Architecture, and Other Cultural Works">{{cite book|last=Harpring|first=Patricia|title=Introduction to Controlled Vocabularies: Terminology for Art, Architecture, and Other Cultural Works|year=2010|publisher=Getty Publications|isbn=160606018X|url=http://www.getty.edu/research/publications/electronic_publications/intro_controlled_vocab/index.html|accessdate=2 April 2013|format=Online Edition|chapter=Vocabularies for Cultural Objects}}</ref>
In the CONA database, each work's record (also called a subject in the database, not to be confused with iconographical depicted subjects of art works) is identified by a unique numeric ID. Linked to each work's record are titles/names, current location, dates, other fields, related works, a parent (that is, a position in the hierarchy), sources for the data, and notes. By using terms from all four Getty Vocabularies to control many of these fields, CONA uses [[linked data]] principles to pull together multiple vocabularies in the creation of an authority file for works of art.<ref name="L.A. meta (data): Exploring vocabulary interoperability in libraries, Archives and Museums">{{cite journal|last=Mitchell|first=Erik|author2=T. Kanti Srikantaiah|title=L.A. meta (data): Exploring vocabulary interoperability in libraries, Archives and Museums|journal=Proceedings of the American Society for Information Science and Technology|year=2012|volume=49|issue=1|pages=1–4 [2]|doi=10.1002/meet.14504901280}}</ref> The coverage of CONA is global, from prehistory through the present.
== History ==
Detailed discussions regarding the Getty Vocabulary Program compiling a vocabulary comprising unique numeric identifiers and brief records for art works began in 2004. It was determined that various Getty projects collected data for movable works and architecture that could form an initial data set, upon which other contributors could build over time. The project was enthusiastically embraced by the user community. In 2005 mapping of the data model used for all three existing vocabularies (the [[Art & Architecture Thesaurus]] (AAT), the [[Thesaurus for Geographic Names]] (TGN), and the [[Union List of Artist Names]] (ULAN)) to potential CONA fields was completed. The effort coincided with the development of CCO (Cataloging Cultural Objects), a more concise offshoot of the CDWA ([[Categories for the Description of Works of Art]]), and CDWA Lite, which is an XML schema intended to serve as an exchange format for art information. Both CCO and CDWA, which reflect consensus in the user community of best practice in cataloging art and architecture, lay out the required fields and rules for cataloging art objects.
Technical development of CONA began in 2010. The editorial system and online search screens for CONA are similar to those used for the existing Getty vocabularies. The data is compiled and edited in an editorial system that was custom-built by Getty technical staff to meet the unique requirements of compiling data from many contributors, building complex and changing polyhierarchies, merging, moving, and publishing in various formats. Final editorial control of CONA is maintained by the Getty Vocabulary Program, using well-established editorial rules.
Contributions to CONA from the user community commenced in 2012. A pilot release of CONA with a limited number of records is currently available online. The growth and utility of CONA will depend upon contributions from users. As with the AAT, TGN, and ULAN, CONA will grow and change via contributions from the user community and editorial work of the [[Getty Vocabulary Program]].
The current manager of the Getty vocabularies is Patricia Harpring, Managing Editor. Administratively, the Vocabulary Program resides under the GRI Collection Management and Description Division (David Farneth, Head). Other GRI departments in this division are General Collection Cataloging, Special Collections Cataloging, Digital Services, the Registrar\x92s Office, Institutional Records and Archives, and Conservation and Preservation. The Vocabulary Program works with Digital Art History Access (Murtha Baca, Head) to foster foreign language translations of the vocabularies, maintain national and international partnerships, and oversee licensing and marketing.<ref>[http://www.getty.edu/research/tools/vocabularies/cona/about.html About CONA]</ref>
== Terms ==
The focus of each CONA record is a work of art or architecture. Each work is identified with a unique and persistent numeric ID, which aids in the disambiguation of similar works.<ref name="The Cataloging Cultural Objects experience: Codifying practice for the cultural heritage community">{{cite journal|last=Coburn|first=Erin|title=The Cataloging Cultural Objects experience: Codifying practice for the cultural heritage community|journal=IFLA journal|year=2010|volume=36|issue=1|pages=16–29 [24]|doi=10.1177/0340035209359561|display-authors=etal}}</ref> There are many fields in CONA, however through titles/names (equivalence relationships), as well as hierarchical and associative relationships, the basic structure of CONA is that of a thesaurus in compliance with ISO and NISO standards. Names or titles may be current, historical, and in various languages.
== Design ==
Although it may be displayed as a list, CONA is a hierarchical database; its trees branch from a root called Top of the CONA hierarchy (Subject_ID: 700000000). There may be multiple broader contexts, making CONA polyhierarchical. In addition to the hierarchical relationships (e.g., between a print and the larger volume to which it belongs), CONA has equivalence relationships (between equivalent titles/names) and associative relationships (e.g., between a sketch and the final work).<ref name="The Getty Vocabularies: “Non-Authoritarian” Authority Files for Art, Architecture, and Material Culture">{{cite web|last=Baca|first=Murtha|title=The Getty Vocabularies: "Non-Authoritarian" Authority Files for Art, Architecture, and Material Culture|url=http://niso.kavi.com/apps/group_public/download.php/5750/NISOauthdatawebinar9feb2011_WEB.pdf|work=NISO Authority Data & Semantic Web Webinar|accessdate=2 April 2013|format=Webinar|date=9 February 2011}}</ref> The primary top divisions of CONA are the facets Built Work and Movable Work.
With the exception of performance art, CONA records unique physical works. However, CONA may include works that were never built or that no longer exist, for example designs for a building that was not constructed or a work that has been destroyed.
'''Built Works''': Built works within the scope of CONA are architecture, which includes structures or parts of structures that are the result of conscious construction, are of practical use, are relatively stable and permanent, and are of a size and scale appropriate for—but not limited to—habitable buildings. Most built works in CONA are manifestations of the built environment that is typically classified as fine art, meaning it is generally considered to have aesthetic value, was designed by an architect (whether or not his or her name is known), and constructed with skilled labor.
'''Movable Works''': The term movable works is borrowed from legal jargon, referring to tangible objects capable of being moved or conveyed from one place to another, as opposed to real estate or other buildings. It is useful to separate the two types of works—built works and movable works—into different facets in CONA because movable works typically are located in a repository, have a repository identification number, have a provenance of former locations, and other characteristics that typically differ from architecture.
Movable works within the scope of CONA include the visual arts that are of the type collected by art museums, although the objects themselves may actually be held by an ethnographic, anthropological, or other museum, or owned by a private collector. Performance art is included in CONA under this facet as well.
The minimum fields and editorial rules of CONA are in compliance with CDWA and CCO.<ref name="Museum Data Exchange: Learning How to Share">{{cite journal|last=Waibel|first=Günter|author2=Ralph LeVan |author3=Bruce Washburn |title=Museum Data Exchange: Learning How to Share|journal=D-Lib Magazine|date=March–April 2010|volume=16|issue=3/4|doi=10.1045/march2010-waibel}}</ref> The minimum fields are the following: Catalog Level, Object/Work Type, Title or Name, Creator, Creation Date, Measurements, Materials and Techniques, Depicted Subject, and Current Location.

== See also ==

== External links == *[http://www.getty.edu/research/tools/vocabularies/cona/ Cultural Objects Name Authority Online] Search CONA online for free. *[http://www.getty.edu/research/conducting_research/vocabularies/ About the Getty Vocabularies] *[http://www.getty.edu/research/tools/vocabularies/cona/about.html About CONA] *[http://www.getty.edu/research/conducting_research/vocabularies/editorial_guidelines.html Getty Vocabulary Editorial Guidelines] The editorial guidelines for the AAT, ULAN, and TGN contain rules and guidelines intended for use by the editors of the Getty Vocabulary Program using the in-house editorial system, VCS (Vocabulary Coordination System). Contributors to the Getty Vocabularies and implementers of the licensed vocabulary data may consult these guidelines as well. *[http://www.getty.edu/research/conducting_research/vocabularies/training.html Training materials and presentations created by the Getty Vocabulary Program] The documents on this page include presentations and other training materials for the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names (TGN), the Union List of Artist Names (ULAN), the Art & Architecture Thesaurus (AAT), Cataloging Cultural Objects (CCO), Categories for the Description of Works of Art (CDWA), and standards in general.

[[Briony Cruden]] | country = Scotland | network = [[Online]] | first_aired = 30 July 2014 | last_aired = 18 September 2014 | num_episodes = 10 |}} '''''Dateline Scotland''''' is a Scottish [[satire]] of television [[Current affairs (news format)|current affairs programmes]], broadcast in 2014, created by [[Jack Foster (director)|Jack Foster]], [[James Devoy]] and [[Jonathan Cairney]]. ''Dateline Scotland'' is composed of eight 5-6 minute episodes and a 15 minute special, released to coincide with the [[Scottish independence referendum]] polling day. The eight 5 minute episodes were originally broadcast online, from 30 July to 17 September 2014 online. A one-off special of the programme was also released in May 2015, to coincide with the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|UK general election]]. ==Programme format== Each episode is presented as a parody news programme, anchored by Foster and Devoy, featuring 3-4 spoof stories based on the previous week’s news. ''Dateline Scotland'' was produced in the final 2 months of the 2014 [[Scottish independence referendum]], and the programme’s content is reflective of this.{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/arts-ents/tv-radio/tv-review-whats-funny-about-the-indyref.1410300115 |title=TV review: What's funny about the indyref? |first=Julie |last=McDowall |work=[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]] |date=9 September 2014|accessdate=27 December 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/scottish-independence-blog/2014/aug/01/scottish-independence-referendum-weekly-review-trains-teacakes-and-telly|title=Scottish independence referendum weekly review: trains, teacakes and telly|first=Libby|last=Brooks|date=1 August 2014|publisher=|accessdate=7 July 2016}} It has been suggested that the show's popularity was related to a dissatisfaction amongst independence supporters with the mainstream Scottish media, with regards its coverage of the referendum.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/sara-sheridan/scottish-independence_b_5784106.html|title=The Flowering of Satire in the Caledonian Spring|date=9 September 2014|publisher=|accessdate=7 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/politics/viewpoint/indie-tv-options-for-coverage-of-the-indy-debate.1413811715|title=Indie TV options for coverage of the indy debate|publisher=|accessdate=7 July 2016}} ==Main characters== * '''Jack Foster''' ([[Jack Foster (director)|Jack Foster]]) – Anchor * '''James Devoy''' ([[James Devoy]]) – Anchor * '''Briony Laing''' ([[Briony Cruden]]) – Various correspondents * '''George Deary''' ([[Jonathan Cairney]]) – Director of Strategy for the [[Better Together (campaign)|Better Together]] campaign (parody). One-off correspondents who appeared in the Referendum Day Special, include Coletta Samson ([[Sandra O’Sullivan]]), Thomas Capes ([[Matthew Houlihan]]), Achiltibuie Corrospondent ([[Dan Devoy]]). Political cartoonist [[Greg Moodie]] also guests as ''Leroy Jenkmans'', “Chief Strategist for [[Yes Scotland]]” (Parody). ==Cast and crew== *[[Jack Foster (director)|Jack Foster]] – Anchor *[[James Devoy]] – Anchor *[[Jonathan Cairney]] – George Deary (also Seb Foucault and Piers Morgen) *[[Briony Laing]] – Various Correspondent roles *Devisers – Jack Foster and James Devoy *Writers - Jack Foster, James Devoy, Jonathan Cairney, the cast *Directors - [[Jack Foster (director)|Jack Foster]] and [[James Devoy]] *Producers - Jack Foster and James Devoy ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} *{{IMDb title|3990536}} *[https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2yulVvCkSPFoZMi-zU0M5A/ Official YouTube channel] {{DEFAULTSORT:Dateline Scotland}} [[Category:Scottish humour]] [[Category:Parodies]] [[Category:News parodies]] [[Category:Scottish satirical television programmes]] [[Category:British mockumentary television series]] [[Category:Television series about television]] [[Category:British satire]]

{{Infobox scientist |name = David Germano |image = File:David Germano.jpg |caption = |birth_date = |birth_place = |residence = [[Charlottesville]], [[Virginia]] |citizenship = [[United States]] |nationality = [[US]] |ethnicity = |fields = |workplaces = [[University of Virginia]] |alma_mater = [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] |thesis_title = Poetic thought, the intelligent Universe, and the mystery self: The Tantric synthesis of rDzogs Chen in fourteenth century Tibet |doctoral_advisor = |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |known_for = [[Tibetology]] |influences = |influenced = |awards = |footnotes = }} '''David Francis Germano''' is an American [[Tibetology|Tibetologist]] and Professor of Tibetan and Buddhist Studies at the [[University of Virginia]] (UVa),<ref name=DG-RS>{{cite web |url=http://religiousstudies.virginia.edu/faculty/profile/dfg9w |title=David Germano |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website= UVa Religious Studies |publisher=UVa |accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref> the largest Tibetan Studies program in the Americas, where he has taught and researched since 1992. With dual appointments in the School of Nursing and the Department of Religious Studies, Germano currently oversees the work of over twenty graduate students.<ref name=DG-C>{{cite web |url=http://uvacontemplation.org/content/david-germano |title=David Germano |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Contemplative Sciences Center |publisher=UVa |accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref><ref name=DG-CV>{{cite web|url=http://www.iwl.virginia.edu/sites/www.iwl.virginia.edu/files/David%20Germano%20C.V.pdf |title=David F. Germano C.V. |author= |date=2013 |website= |publisher=University of Virginia }}{{dead link|date=March 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He is on the board of the International Association of Tibetan Studies<ref>http://www.iats.info/people/</ref> and is Editor-in-Chief of [[JIATS|The Journal of the International Association of Tibetan Studies]] (JIATS),<ref>{{Citation | <!-- editor-last = Germano | editor-first = David --> |date= August 2013 |title= The Journal of the International Association of Tibetan Studies|issue= 7|publisher= The International Association of Tibetan Studies|website = Tibetan and Himalayan Library|url=http://www.thlib.org/collections/texts/jiats/#!jiats=/current/ |issn=1550-6363| accessdate= 7 August 2014}}</ref> a leading journal of Tibetology.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://library.columbia.edu/locations/eastasian/tibetan/guide/tibetan_studies.html |title=Tibetan Studies: |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Columbia University Libraries Information Services |publisher=Columbia University |accessdate= 7 August 2014}}</ref> In 2000, he founded the [[Tibetan and Himalayan Library]], a digital initiative for collaborative building of knowledge on the region, which he continues to lead as Director.<ref name=DG-C /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://chnm.gmu.edu/worldhistorysources/r/155/whm.html |title=Tibetan and Himalayan Digital Library |last1=DeCaroli |first1=Robert |date=August 2003 |website=World History Sources|publisher=Roy Rosenzweig Center for History and New Media, George Mason University, |accessdate=2014-08-13}}</ref> Since 2008 he has also been the co-director of the UVa Tibet Center.<ref name=DG-T>{{cite web |url=http://www.uvatibetcenter.org/?page_id=1699 |title=David Germano |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=UVa Tibet Center |publisher=UVa |accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref> More recently, Germano acted as the founding director of SHANTI (Sciences, Humanities and the Arts Network of Technological Initiatives) at the UVa.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://shanti.virginia.edu/ |title=SHANTI |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Sciences, Humanities and the Arts Network of Technological Initiatives |publisher= University of Virginia}}</ref> Since 2011, Germano has also played a leading role in organizing the University of Virginia's Contemplative Sciences Center, which he currently directs.<ref>http://uvacontemplation.org/content/david-germano</ref>
== Education ==
He received a Bachelor of Arts (BA) from the [[University of Notre Dame]], and a Doctor of Philosophy (PhD), from [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]], where he focused in Buddhist Studies and Tibetan Studies.<ref name=DG-CV>{{cite web|url=http://www.iwl.virginia.edu/sites/www.iwl.virginia.edu/files/David%20Germano%20C.V.pdf |title=David F. Germano C.V. |author= |date=2013 |website= |publisher=University of Virginia }}{{dead link|date=March 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He has also spent over a decade living and studying in various parts of Asia, particularly in regions with high concentrations of Tibetans and other Himalayan Buddhists are located - Tibet, China, Bhutan, India, and Nepal.<ref>"Living Relics of the Buddha(s) in Tibet," Germano, David. ''Embodying the Dharma: Buddhist Relic Veneration in Asia.'' Edited by David Germano and Kevin Trainor. Albany: State University of New York, 2004. 51-92.</ref>
== Research interests ==
Germano's research interests include philosophical and contemplative traditions in Tibet, particularly [[Dzogchen]] in the [[Nyingma]] and [[Bön]] traditions and Tibetan historical literature. He also researches on the contemporary state of Tibetan religion in relationship to China and non-monastic yogic communities in cultural Tibet.<ref name=DG-RS>{{cite web |url=http://religiousstudies.virginia.edu/faculty/profile/dfg9w |title=David Germano |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website= UVa Religious Studies |publisher=UVa |accessdate=25 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://indiachinainstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/FINAL_ParticipantBios.pdf |title=Erseh Project Groups:Participants Bios|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=India China Institute |publisher=The New School |location=New York |page=8|accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref> He is currently working on a fourfold set of works constituting a comprehensive analysis of the Great Perfection Seminal Heart (''rdzogs chen snying thig'') tradition from its early formation to its full expression in the fourteenth century within the works of [[Longchenpa]]. This will include a deeply annotated translation of one of Longchenpa's major works, ''The Treasury of Words and Meanings'' (''tshig don mdzod'') and detailed studies of the Seminal Heart tradition itself from historical, philosophical, and literary perspectives respectively.<ref name=DG-RS />
== Publications and academic contributions == [[File:Karma Phuntsho and David Germano.jpg|thumb|[[Karma Phuntsho|Dr. Karma Phuntsho]] and Dr. David Germano - Thimphu, Bhutan. 4 August, 2013]] Germano's academic work primarily focuses around two complementary poles: the contours of Nyingma philosophy, doctrine, and practice (particularly as found in the Dzogs chen school) and how these religious lineages have been interacted with, embodied, and understood throughout Tibetan history. Germano is passionate that contemporary academic work support, benefit, and honor the preservation of Tibetan culture and Tibetan ways-of-life today, giving rise to many of his academic projects.<ref name=DG-CV>{{cite web|url=http://www.iwl.virginia.edu/sites/www.iwl.virginia.edu/files/David%20Germano%20C.V.pdf |title=David F. Germano C.V. |author= |date=2013 |website= |publisher=University of Virginia }}{{dead link|date=March 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In particular, much of the work David leads at the Tibetan and Himalayan Library has been geared towards not only making academic resources accessible for Tibetans, but also towards mapping and collecting traditional knowledge of Tibetan peoples today. A sampling of the collaborative work Germano leads includes the [http://places.thlib.org/ Tibetan Place Dictionary], the [http://www.thlib.org/places/maps/collections/ Tibetan Map Collection], and the [http://www.thlib.org/avarch/mediaflowcat/ Tibetan Audio-Video Archive].<ref name=DG-CV>{{cite web|url=http://www.iwl.virginia.edu/sites/www.iwl.virginia.edu/files/David%20Germano%20C.V.pdf |title=David F. Germano C.V. |author= |date=2013 |website= |publisher=University of Virginia }}{{dead link|date=March 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Beyond these specific projects, Germano organizes several important programs to bring Tibetan thinkers to study in America and facilitate the development of long-lasting academic connections between Tibetan and American scholars, including the [http://www.uvatibetcenter.org/?page_id=6573 University of Virginia Tibetan Entrepreneurs Program] and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20150714162652/http://www.uvatibetcenter.org/?page_id=5055 Education to Employment Initiative].<ref>http://www.uvatibetcenter.org/</ref>
As part of his interest in supporting contemporary Tibetan peoples, Germano also works to introduce those outside Tibetan cultural areas to the richness and depth of traditional Tibetan culture. He has written numerous encyclopedia articles and annotated textual entries for the ''Encyclopedia of Religion'' (Macmillian Reference, 2004) and ''Religions of Tibet in Practice'' ([[Princeton University Press]], 1997).<ref name=DG-CV>{{cite web|url=http://www.iwl.virginia.edu/sites/www.iwl.virginia.edu/files/David%20Germano%20C.V.pdf |title=David F. Germano C.V. |author= |date=2013 |website= |publisher=University of Virginia }}{{dead link|date=March 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He has also been involved with numerous documentary works on traditional Tibetan arts, including the 2004 documentary ''Tibetan Furniture Making: Traditions and Innovations,'' produced for the Pacific Asian Art Museum in Los Angeles, CA.<ref name=DG-CV>{{cite web|url=http://www.iwl.virginia.edu/sites/www.iwl.virginia.edu/files/David%20Germano%20C.V.pdf |title=David F. Germano C.V. |author= |date=2013 |website= |publisher=University of Virginia }}{{dead link|date=March 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In 2014, Germano was the keynote speaker for the Mind and Life Institute conference "Contemplation in Contexts: Tibetan Buddhist Meditation Across the Boundaries of the Humanities and Sciences."<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QEciEIaAUMM</ref> Recently, Germano's work as Director of the Contemplative Sciences Center has allowed him to coordinate the interests of numerous innovators, researchers, and scholars to investigate the benefits of contemplative activities.<ref name="uvacontemplation.org">http://uvacontemplation.org/</ref> In this context, he has led a larger effort to think about the nature and future of a large public research university in the context of the transformative possibilities offered by contemplative practices, ideas, and values.<ref name="uvacontemplation.org"/> Germano has also used this position to bring an increasing academic rigor as well as an acknowledgment of the foundational importance of culture to discussions of meditation and contemplation.<ref name="uvacontemplation.org"/>
Beyond these innovative contributions to academic scholarship and public knowledge, Germano has also edited two volumes and written several articles published in both online and print academic journals.<ref name=DG-CV>{{cite web|url=http://www.iwl.virginia.edu/sites/www.iwl.virginia.edu/files/David%20Germano%20C.V.pdf |title=David F. Germano C.V. |author= |date=2013 |website= |publisher=University of Virginia }}{{dead link|date=March 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> These works continue to explore how Tibetans have practiced and understood Dzogs chen philosophy and cultural identity both throughout history and today.
